messageBody:
Hi isaachanstar

I'm assuming you know the basics but just in case you don't I'll briefly
summarise. Write your plug-in tests in a second plug-in project to the
one under test, export the packages from the first to make them visible
and run the tests as JUnit plug-in tests to let PDE launch an Eclipse
runtime for you in which the tests will be run. Warning, this is slow!

Chapter 12 of Erich Gamma and Kent Beck's "Contributing to Eclipse:
Principles, Patterns and Plug-ins" gives good advice that may be useful.
That chapter is available as a pdf download:
http://today.java.net/today/2004/02/02/ch12Eclipse.pdf#search=%22test%20driven%20plugin%20development%20pdf%22

It is also worth getting hold of a copy of the book because, even if the
code examples are a little out of date (written for Eclipse 2.1.1), the
patterns and principles still apply.

The second edition of "Eclipse Building Commercial-Quality Plug-ins" by
Eric Clayberg and Dan Rubel is also helpful (and covers Eclipse
3.1/3.2). The authors develop a plug-in over the course of the book and
while they don't practice TDD, they do show how they develop unit-tests
for some of the functionality.

Also, look at David Saff and Michael Ernst's paper "Mock Object Creation
for Test Factoring" in which they raise the idea of mocking the Eclipse
platform in order to remove the time it takes to launch the Eclipse
runtime when testing plug-ins.
http://pag.csail.mit.edu/pubs/mock-factoring-paste2004-abstract.html

Unit-testing plug-ins is hard work. As mentioned launching the tests in
a runtime workspace via PDE adds a significant overhead to execution
time which makes it frustratingly slow. Moreover, setting up the test
fixture takes a lot of time and demands a deeper knowledge of how
Eclipse manages its components than you would expect to need at first,
far more than you need to develop simple plug-ins without tests. (Note,
this in no doubt true of writing unit-tests while working with any
platform: I'm very much a beginner in this field and have nothing with
which to compare the experience.)

Hope this helps

Tim
